docs.lead_paragraph: ALMOST everyone who flies has spent at least part of a night at an airport hotel. Predawn departures, missed connections, canceled flights, oversold seats: all sorts of things can lead to a sleepless stay, watching car headlights flicker across the ceiling and hearing planes taking off and landing. We stalled travelers are known in airport-hotel jargon as ''distress'' customers. The phrase is usually apt: already pained by the forces that brought us there, we are still more distressed by the place we have been deposited. But hotels at airports are changing. Figures from Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., show that airport hotels nationally had a 70.5 percent occupancy rate last year, which outstripped other sorts of hotels from luxury to budget. For this year, until September, the figure was 71.3 percent. An analysis by the magazine Hotel and Motel Management cited as causes both an improvement in facilities -- business centers, fitness centers and tennis courts -- and an overflow of guests from downtown hotels.

headline.main: Hotels at J.F.K. Buff Their Image
